appeals.sector: Cuba, Haiti and Dominican Republic country cluster
Cuba, Haiti and Dominican Republic country cluster

field_reports.description:
After previously passing through the Bahamas, Category 1 Hurricane Oscar made landfall Sunday in eastern Cuba at 17:50 local time (23:50 GMT), as the country continues attempts to restore the power grid amid a massive blackout.

The storm had already made landfall on Great Inagua Island in the Bahamas in the early morning, with winds of up to 130 kilometres per hour (80 mph).

Oscar's rapid increase in intensity from a tropical storm to a 135-kilometre-per-hour (85 mph) hurricane alerted the islands in its path.

The small cyclone is considered one of the smallest in size on record in the Atlantic Basin, which could mean rapid fluctuations in intensity due to its ability to take advantage of specific conditions such as dry air and shear.


Oscar, originally designated as Invest 94L, poses a significant threat to areas in its path. However, 'it is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it moves across eastern Cuba during Sunday night and Monday,' the National Hurricane Center said.

Despite this expected weakening, torrential rains and high winds are still anticipated for the region, and hurricane warnings have been issued for the northern coast of Cuba's Holguín and Guantánamo provinces as far as Punta Maisí.

Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines (Minem) reported on Sunday the third total outage of the National Electric System (SEN) in less than three days.

'A few minutes ago there was another disconnection of the Electrical System, SEN. Immediately began the work of restoration,' Minem wrote on social networks.

The first total system outage, the first event of 'zero national energy coverage', according to the Minem, occurred on Friday morning, after an 'unforeseen' output of a key power plant for the SEN destabilised the entire system.

results.name: CUB: Cyclone - 10-2024 - Hurricane Oscar
results.summary:
After previously passing through the Bahamas, Category 1 Hurricane Oscar made landfall Sunday in eastern Cuba at 17:50 local time (23:50 GMT), as the country continues attempts to restore the power grid amid a massive blackout.

The storm had already made landfall on Great Inagua Island in the Bahamas in the early morning, with winds of up to 130 kilometres per hour (80 mph).

Oscar's rapid increase in intensity from a tropical storm to a 135-kilometre-per-hour (85 mph) hurricane alerted the islands in its path.

The small cyclone is considered one of the smallest in size on record in the Atlantic Basin, which could mean rapid fluctuations in intensity due to its ability to take advantage of specific conditions such as dry air and shear.


Oscar, originally designated as Invest 94L, poses a significant threat to areas in its path. However, 'it is expected to weaken to a tropical storm as it moves across eastern Cuba during Sunday night and Monday,' the National Hurricane Center said.

Despite this expected weakening, torrential rains and high winds are still anticipated for the region, and hurricane warnings have been issued for the northern coast of Cuba's Holguín and Guantánamo provinces as far as Punta Maisí.

Cuba's Ministry of Energy and Mines (Minem) reported on Sunday the third total outage of the National Electric System (SEN) in less than three days.

The first total system outage, the first event of 'zero national energy coverage', according to the Minem, occurred on Friday morning, after an 'unforeseen' output of a key power plant for the SEN destabilised the entire system.

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description: It’s been four weeks since Hurricane Ian slammed into Florida and the American Red Cross is working day and night, alongside their partners, to provide food, shelter and comfort for people facing the heartbreaking devastation left behind by this historic storm. Many neighborhoods that were home to retirees on fixed incomes and mobile home parks have been left unrecognizable and conditions are still making it difficult for people to get aid. With help from their partners, American Red Cross is reaching out to offer relief and support so that no one faces this tough time alone. American Red Cross and its partners have provided 30,824 overnight stays for more than 6,783 residents in 71 emergency shelters. With the help of partners, a total of 1,353,802 meals and snacks have been provided. To date, 352,740 relief items including comfort kits and other supplies have been provided to people in need and 17,010 total households have been served. The operations are supported by 2,252 trained Red Cross disaster workers. Of these, there are 210 who are trained to support health and mental health services, and Spiritual care needs in the shelters and throughout the community. Workers have provided support to 68 EOC locations in the state.

contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description: Before the storm, the American Red Cross moved truckloads of additional cots, blankets and comfort kits, along with tens of thousands of relief supplies into the region to be prepared to help as many as 60,000 people. Dozens of emergency response vehicles are also pre-positioned across the state. AmRC has also sent several hundred blood products to Florida ahead of the storm to ensure patients continue to have access to a readily available blood supply. Since shelters were opened for this disaster, the American Red Cross and its partners have provided 7,145 overnight stays for more than 5,843 residents in 49 emergency shelters. With the help of partners, a total of 4892 meals and snacks have been provided. The operations are supported by 1029 trained Red Cross disaster workers. Of these, there are 53 who are trained to support health and mental health services, and Spiritual care needs in the shelters and throughout the community.

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description: Hurricane Ian made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast on September 28 as a powerful Category 4 storm. The system brought heavy rains and maximum winds of 140 mph, flooding large swaths of the state and disrupting transportation and telecommunication infrastructure. As of September 29, more than 2 million people across the state were without electricity, and hundreds of thousands had evacuated from the storm's path. Damage is expected to be severe and widespread.

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description:
As Hurricane Ian grows stronger and heads toward Florida with dangerous winds, rain and storm surges, the American Red Cross is preparing for its impact. Experts predict Florida could see as much as 15 inches of rain throughout this week which, combined with a dangerous storm surge, may trigger flooding across the state. Ian could be the first major hurricane to strike Florida since 2018.

The American Red Cross is monitoring the situation closely and are working with their partners to shelter and support people in the path of this storm. Hundreds of Red Crossers are being deployed to Florida and in addition to their pre-positioned supplies, more relief supplies are on the way. AmRC is working with local officials and preparing to open hurricane evacuation shelters if requested.

Ahead of the storm, AmRC is actively working as a member of the AABB Task Force for Disease Response and has offered assistance to impacted blood centers. They stand ready to assist with additional blood needs as requested by other blood providers or hospitals.

REPORTE PRELIMINAR SOBRE TRABAJO DE LA SOCIEDAD NACIONAL CUBANA DE LA CRUZ ROJA  EN EL EVENTO DE INCENDIO DE GRAN MAGNITUD EN LA BASE DE SUPERTANQUEROS EL DIA 6 DE AGOSTO DEL 2022. 

 En horas de la tarde noche del día 5 de agosto un rayo impacto sobre un tanque de combustible de la base de súper tanquero de la zona industrial de Matanzas causando un incendio de grandes proporciones.

De  inmediato se presentan en el lugar las fuerzas de bomberos y  defensa civil y el grupo provincial Especializado de  operación y socorro de la Cruz Roja de Matanzas .

Posteriormente se incorporaron voluntarios/as  del  grupo de socorristas de las Provincias de la Habana, Mayabeque y Artemisa.
field_reports.summary: CUB: Chemical Emergency - 2022-08 - Fuel tanks catch fire at Oil Terminal in Matanzas

results.name: CUB: Chemical Emergency - 2022-08 - Fuel tanks catch fire at Oil Terminal in Matanzas
results.summary:
PRELIMINARY REPORT ON THE WORK OF THE CUBAN NATIONAL SOCIETY OF THE RED  CROSS IN THE EVENT OF A FIRE OF GREAT MAGNITUDE AT THE SUPERTANKER BASE ON AUGUST 6, 2022. 

 In the evening hours of August 5, lightning struck a fuel tank at the super tanker base in the industrial zone of Matanzas, causing a fire of great proportions.

The  fire and  civil defense forces and the Specialized Provincial Operation  and Relief Group of the Red Cross of Matanzas immediately arrived at the scene.

Subsequently, volunteers  from the  group of lifeguards from the Provinces of Havana, Mayabeque and Artemisa joined.   

The volunteers have worked on lifeguard actions to remove the victims from the damaged area, have carried out logistics actions and transfer them to the units of the integrated medical emergency system of the National Health System.

They participated in the transfer of the necessary medical supplies for the scene, have supported the hospitals that received the injured and have made blood donations to save lives.

From 6-8-22 we began work of Psychological support and RCF by both the Provincial Branch of Matanzas and the Municipal Branch of Cárdenas.

To date, no search requests have been made, but psychological first aid was provided to CUPET drivers who were waiting to evacuate fuel, to the  families   of the different workers, to the  firefighters  and the first responders themselves and to the people directly affected by the incident. They participated together with the experts of the National Psychology group in the place where the relatives were concentrated, providing this  collaboration.

The RCF office of the Havana Provincial Red Cross was activated to provide  accurate and timely information to the families of the injured who were transferred to Havana Health Units.

This operation is being carried out from the 5th to date, 5 days of uninterrupted work and the forces are maintained on the ground, a total of 103 Red Cross volunteers have participated in different actions.

4 injured volunteers  of the Red Cross of Matanzas  were reported with minor burns without criteria for hospital admission, their families have been accompanied.

The group of journalists who are friends of the Red Cross have been reporting from the first moments through Cuban television and other media and social networks all the necessary information related to the actions and the situation of the volunteers who are participating in the operation.

Cuban TV has broadcast information on the actions of the Red Cross rescuers, they have been interviewed and have expressed their feelings about this situation of great magnitude.

Mention the permanent support of the party and government authorities, as well as other actors, for the good performance of our volunteers on the ground.

appeals.sector: Cuba, Haiti and Dominican Republic country cluster

field_reports.description:
Two boats carrying 844 and 130 people from Haiti, who had intended to reach the United States, landed on the coasts of the municipality of Caibarién, in the provinces of Villa Clara and Holguin. 
The migrants have been accompanied by the Cuban Red Cross and the Cuban authorities through medical assistance and humanitarian aid. They were temporarily transferred to shelters while the established migration processes are carried out in order to ensure a safe and voluntary return to their country of origin.

results.name: Tropical Storm Elsa Monitoring
results.summary:
Context:

Tropical storm Elsa is now off the Florida Keys this morning and will move near or over portions of the west coast of Florida later today through tonight. It is expected to make landfall along the north Florida Gulf coast. El Centro de Pronósticos del Instituto de Meteorología, reports that Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from Cuban territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. All provinces that were on alert are to return to normality and to continue monitoring weather reports.

 

IFRC actions:

·       IFRC has been following up on Elsa since 28-June when it was forecasted to reach the Caribbean

·       Closely coordinating with the NSs of Barbados, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Jamaica and Cuba

·       A total of 6 information messages and 1 bulletin have been issued

·       1 JFT and multiple coordination meetings with the country cluster delegations in Port of Spain and Santo Domingo

·       Tropical Storm Monitoring Dashboard: https://go.ifrc.org/emergencies/5379#details

·       IFRC Disaster Managers (DMs) and Disaster Preparedness Coordinator attending daily meetings with the CDPG

·       The Regional Logistics Unit (RLU) has been closely monitoring and preparing for a possible response

·       Preparedness Dashboard https://go.ifrc.org/regions/1#additional-info

·       The Communications Team has been in contact with NSs, has shared key messages, press release templates and preparedness messages on social media

·       The Community engagement and accountability (CEA) team has been in contact with NSs, sharing and gathering Information. The CEA team also shared the Hurricane Preparedness CEA summary tools and follows up with NSs

·       IFRC will continue monitoring and following up with National Societies

 

Cuban Red Cross:

·       According to the information from the Forecasting Center of the Institute of Meteorology, Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from the national territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. Therefore, it was decided to return to normality in the provinces of Sancti Spíritus, Cienfuegos, Villa Clara, Matanzas, Mayabeque, Havana, Artemisa, Pinar del Rio and the Isla de la Juventud Special Municipality

·       The Ministry of Communications evaluated the damage to the communications system caused by tropical storm Elsa and so far no serious damage has been detected

·       No major damages have been reported in the country and the government is responding to the affectations

·       The NS volunteers and staff are on alert and assisting in the needs assessments

·       The governor of the province of Matanzas assured that in spite of the persistent rains of tropical storm Elsa, it did not cause significant damage in the territory. The abundance of rainfall, the overflowing of rivers and the runoff caused flooding in low-lying areas and forced the evacuation of hundreds of people, as happened in the La Marina neighbourhood in the provincial capital

·       In total, more than 2,000 people were evacuated in state-run centres in the province and some 20,000 people found protection in the homes of family and friends and will be receiving support from the government

·       More than 20 percent of the population was without electricity service, and by late morning the restitution of the service was advancing at an accelerated pace. The director of the Electricity Company said that some 42 areas were without electricity service, which affected some 84,000 customers. It has already been restored for 12,000. 95 percent of the service should be resolved this Tuesday
